Bills Releasing Lotulelei
As Getzenberg noted, the Bills had already restructured Lotulelei’s $50 million contract in 2020 to save on salary cap space, but it was still too high of a number for a team looking to get out from a tight cap situation.

As Nick Wojton of USA Today’s Bills Wire noted, Settle showed some strong potential in Washington but had difficulty getting snaps in the crowded defensive line rotation, and could have more of a chance to shine with the Bills.

Just one day after the rather surprising announcement that the team was signing edge rusher Von Miller to a $120 million deal, the Bills announced that they were parting ways with defensive lineman Star Lotulelei.
The 32-year-old tackle had initially signed with the Bills on a five-year, $50 million deal in 2018, but he has missed much of the last two seasons with a COVID-19 opt-out and a series of injuries.
Harrison Phillips, who largely filled in for Lotulelei during his absence this season, left to join the Minnesota Vikings and the Bills brought in more depth with a pair of other acquisitions.

Lotulelei had missed all of the 2020 season, opting out due to COVID-19, and missed more time last season for a COVID-19 infection and for personal reasons.
The Bills could have lowered this number by designating Lotulelei as a post-June 1 release, but they instead decided to take a more immediate cap saving of $1.5 million.
The Buffalo Bills have already made one of the biggest additions in free agency, and now are making another widely expected subtraction to create more cap space.
They signed former Carolina Panthers lineman DaQuan Jones, who is seen as a strong run stopper playing largely the same role as both Phillips and Lotulelei.
Bills general manager Brandon Beane had already warned that the team would need to make some moves to create space, and that was before Miller’s signing.
As ESPN writer Alaina Getzenberg noted, many had expected that the Bills would be releasing Lotulelei to reap the salary cap savings.
“Ultimately, the writing was on the wall for the end of Lotulelei’s time with the Bills,” Getzenberg wrote.
